The United Kingdom’s largest industry by revenue – the grocery and retail sector – relies on highly efficient logistics networks to move goods from suppliers to stores and customers ([Supermarkets in the UK - Market Research Report (2015-2030)](https://www.ibisworld.com/united-kingdom/market-research-reports/supermarkets-industry/#:~:text=%282015,it%27s%20expected%20to%20inch)).

Dijkstra’s algorithm, for example, efficiently finds the minimum-distance route between two points and has relatively low complexity on sparse road networks ([](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2205.15190#:~:text=One%20of%20the%20main%20advantages,A%20balance%20function%20between%20distance)).
***
A* search improves on Dijkstra by using heuristics (like straight-line distance) to guide the search, making it faster for point-to-point navigation.
***
The Bellman-Ford algorithm can handle graphs with negative edge weights (useful for certain scheduling costs) and computes shortest paths in a dynamic programming manner.
***
These traditional algorithms have been effective for static routing problems, such as mapping services that find a single best path.
***
However, they have notable limitations in the context of complex logistics routing.
***
They typically handle one origin–destination pair at a time and assume static road conditions; they do not natively solve multi-stop route planning or account for real-time changes.
***
In practice, the Vehicle Routing Problem (VRP) – finding optimal routes for a fleet serving many stops – is NP-hard and cannot be directly solved by simple graph algorithms when the problem size grows (even a few hundred delivery nodes makes exact solutions intractable) ([Reinforcement Learning for Solving the Vehicle Routing Problem](http://papers.neurips.cc/paper/8190-reinforcement-learning-for-solving-the-vehicle-routing-problem.pdf#:~:text=few%20hundred%20customer%20nodes%20,15%2C%2023%2C%2024%2C%2033)).
***
Moreover, real-world factors like time windows, vehicle capacities, and traffic variability violate the static assumptions of these algorithms.
***
As one study noted, improvements to Dijkstra’s algorithm can yield faster route calculations, but “none of them actually solved the vehicle routing problem dynamically” given that traffic conditions and delivery requests change continuously ([](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2205.15190#:~:text=Although%20the%20above%20studies%20tried,math.OC%5D%2030%20May%202022)).
***
In summary, while Dijkstra’s and related algorithms are indispensable for basic route computation, their scope is limited.
***
Logistics planners have traditionally supplemented them with human expertise or simple heuristics (like the savings algorithm or nearest-neighbor for TSP) to build multi-stop routes, but this often yields suboptimal results in complex scenarios.

**Role of LLMs and Unstructured Data Analysis:**
***
A new frontier in logistics AI is the use of large language models (LLMs) and natural language processing.
***
Logistics operations generate and depend on a wealth of unstructured textual data: customer delivery instructions, driver notes, traffic and weather advisories, news of disruptions, social media feedback, and more.
***

**AI-Driven Solution Techniques:**
***
The core optimization techniques considered are:
- **Genetic Algorithms (GA):** We will use GAs to generate high-quality solutions to routing problems such as the Vehicle Routing Problem.
***
A GA encodes routes as chromosomes (for example, a sequence of delivery stops for a vehicle) and applies evolutionary operators to iteratively improve them.
***
This approach is well-suited for logistics because it can handle complex constraints (capacities, time windows) and multiple objectives by designing appropriate fitness functions.
***
Prior research has shown GAs effectively optimizing routes in various logistics scenarios, from city deliveries to inter-city transport ([Artificial Intelligence in Logistics Optimization with Sustainable Criteria: A Review](https://www.mdpi.com/2071-1050/16/21/9145#:~:text=proposed%20by%20Yang%20et%20al,based%20on%20the%20long%20short)).
***
We will leverage libraries like **DEAP (Distributed Evolutionary Algorithms in Python)
***
** for implementing the GA, which allows custom representation of routes and parallel execution to speed up convergence.
***
- **Reinforcement Learning (RL):** For dynamic, real-time routing optimization, we propose developing an RL agent.
***
The routing process is formulated as a Markov Decision Process where the state includes all pending deliveries and vehicle locations, and the agent’s action is to decide the next stop or vehicle assignment.
***
Using frameworks such as **OpenAI Gym** (to simulate the logistics environment) and deep RL algorithms (Deep Q-Networks or policy-gradient methods), the agent can learn a policy that minimizes a long-term cost (like total delivery time or fuel use).
***
Over many training episodes, the RL agent will improve by learning from reward feedback – for example, it gets higher rewards for shorter route completions.
***
The trained policy can then make decisions on the fly during actual operations, adapting to new orders or disruptions.
***
This approach addresses the need for **real-time decision-making**: rather than solving routes once and fixing them, the RL agent continuously refines routes as conditions change.

**AI for Route Optimization:**
***
Routing problems such as the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP) and Vehicle Routing Problem (VRP) have long been a proving ground for AI optimization methods.
***
**Genetic Algorithms (GA)**, as discussed, are a popular choice to tackle these problems.
***
For instance, a GA can be applied to the TSP (a single vehicle visiting many locations) by encoding each possible tour as a chromosome and evolving the population to minimize the tour length ([Two-Stage Genetic Algorithm for Optimization Logistics Network for Groupage Delivery](https://www.mdpi.com/2076-3417/14/24/12005#:~:text=novel%20clustering%20based%20genetic%20algorithm,route%20optimization%20for%20waste%20collection)).
***
This approach has been successfully used in city logistics planning; one case study showed GA-based optimization improved delivery route efficiency by reducing total distance traveled ([Two-Stage Genetic Algorithm for Optimization Logistics Network for Groupage Delivery](https://www.mdpi.com/2076-3417/14/24/12005#:~:text=novel%20clustering%20based%20genetic%20algorithm,route%20optimization%20for%20waste%20collection)).
***
In more complex VRPs involving multiple vehicles and constraints, GA variants (including hybrid GAs combined with local search) have achieved near-optimal solutions within practical compute times ([Two-Stage Genetic Algorithm for Optimization Logistics Network for Groupage Delivery](https://www.mdpi.com/2076-3417/14/24/12005#:~:text=,route%20optimization%20for%20waste%20collection)).
***
These methods are advantageous because they are **flexible** – new constraints (like a maximum route time or a preference for certain delivery sequences) can often be added by tweaking the fitness function or genetic operators, rather than redesigning the whole algorithm.

Such dynamic routing was historically very hard to do manually, but AI can handle the complexity.
***
Techniques like **rolling horizon planning** or **model predictive control** (common in operations research) blend with AI algorithms to continuously solve routing problems as a form of control loop.

***
Evolutionary algorithms can also be run in a sliding window manner to adjust parts of routes.

The main challenge for dynamic optimization is ensuring stability (avoiding too much change that confuses operations) and doing it fast.
***
Modern computation (especially cloud computing and parallel processing) combined with efficient AI algorithms largely mitigates this.
***
The result is a logistics operation that’s **responsive**: it can recover from disruptions (like accidents, urgent orders, or vehicle failures) quickly and with minimal manual intervention.

This leads to improved service levels – customers get updated ETAs promptly and see on-time deliveries even in the face of disruptions.

AI routing systems will need to adapt to manage mixed fleets of human-driven and autonomous vehicles.
***
They might allocate longer or more tedious routes to autonomous trucks (since no human gets tired) and reserve more complex urban deliveries for human drivers (at least in the near term until full autonomy in city streets is solved).

Routing AI could exploit that by scheduling more overnight long hauls for robots.

With drones and robots for last-mile, the routing problem becomes a 3D and multi-vehicle type problem.

Future algorithms will decide, for a set of deliveries, which should be done by van and which by drone, and coordinate between them (e.g., a van might carry drones to a neighborhood, then launch them).
***
This brings in new constraints like drone range, payload, air traffic regulations, etc.
***
